title: Wage-Setting in Britian: Evidence from High-Frequency Firm-Level Data
abstractText:
The process by which wages are determined is very important in many parts of economics.  In macroeconomics, there is a very long-standing debate about the extent of rigidity (nominal or real) in wages and the implications for the response of the macroeconomy to different shocks and the effectiveness of monetary policy.  On the micro side, the way in which wages respond to institutions like the minimum wage is important in understanding the effect of minimum wages on overall inequality.

This project will analyse the previously unstudied UK Monthly Wages and Salary Survey (MWSS).  Unlike most other data sets, the MWSS has a monthly frequency so can be used to analyse short-period changes in wages, critically important if, for example, one wants to evaluate whether it is true that wages are changed annually, or to see if there is any anticipation of future minimum wage increases.

The main aims of the research will be studies of the following issues:

  1. The Frequency of Wage Changes.
  2. The Frequency of Employment Changes.
  3. The Relationship between Employment and Wage Changes.
  4. The Impact of the Minimum Wage on Employment and the Distribution of Wages.
impactText: I gave a talk at HMT Labour Markets Conference on the Average Weekly Earnings Series that used the work on the Monthly Wage and Salaries Survey Government, Democracy and Justice Economic
organisation: London School of Economics & Pol Sci
findingsText: The main finding is that monthly data on earnings per head at the establishment level have a lot of volatility so are probably not useful as an indicator of labour market tightness This might be used to develop an aggregate earnings series better-suited to the needs of users in assessing the state of the labour market Government, Democracy and Justice
